title: A pickup’s persistent plastic pan problems
author: John Paul
bullets: John Paul, AAA Northeast's Car Doctor, advises a reader on their Ford F-150's recurrent leaking plastic oil pan issue.
Ford provides a metal oil pan option, but replacement involves higher labor costs and is not covered under warranty.
Ford's vehicle design includes challenging repairs, such as the Explorer's water pump and GM's buried thermostat in certain engines.

title: Patriots get bad news with injuries ahead of Bucs matchup
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson missed practice due to injuries ahead of game against Tampa Bay Bucs.
Garrett Bradbury didn't participate in practice, potentially affecting the Patriots' offensive line for Sunday's matchup.
Tampa Bay Bucs also have injury concerns with key players like Chris Godwin and Bucky Irving not practicing.

title: Boston youth baseball coach pleads not guilty to drug trafficking charge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Bryan Mejia, 31, youth baseball coach at Boston Athletic Academy, charged with trafficking over 10 grams of fentanyl.
Mejia was arrested for allegedly selling fentanyl to an undercover officer; charge carries up to 20 years in prison.
Mejia pleaded not guilty at arraignment; released on personal recognizance, court hearing set for December 1.

title: Education technology company to close Boston headquarters, embrace fully remote workplace
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Cengage Group will close its Boston, Detroit, and Cincinnati offices, shifting to a fully remote workforce model.
The firm, one of the largest edtech companies, serves 90 million students worldwide with nearly 4,000 employees.
Cengage has integrated generative AI into its platforms and will continue operations with only one U.S. location in Kentucky.

title: What Patriots players did during their off day that impressed Mike Vrabel
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: 41 Patriots players lifted weights on their day off, a positive sign appreciated by Mike Vrabel.
Tuesday is typically a rest day for Patriots players, but many opted to work out at Gillette Stadium.
Stefon Diggs emphasized the team's focus on improvement and not getting complacent despite their 7-2 record.

title: Officials identify two killed in apparent murder-suicide in Beverly
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Becky Lynn Center, 58, and John Patrick Nesbitt, 56, found dead in Beverly home on Colonial Drive.
Officials suspect murder-suicide after the pair were pronounced dead from gunshot wounds at the scene.
Beverly police, Massachusetts State Police, and the Chief Medical Examiner's Office are investigating the case.

title: South Boston man linked to Bulger sentenced to 15 years for involvement in 1984, 1993 cold case killings
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Michael Lewis, linked to James 'Whitey' Bulger, was sentenced to 15 years for two killings in 1984 and 1993.
Lewis pleaded guilty to manslaughter charges for the deaths of Brian Watson and William Villani, initially faced first-degree murder charges.
The sentence was a negotiated plea deal due to risks of trial; authorities cited Bulger's influence in the cases.

title: Olney: Red Sox ‘well-positioned’ to try and trade for Tigers ace Tarik Skubal
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox are reportedly considering a trade for Tigers' ace Tarik Skubal, a 2024 AL Cy Young Award winner.
Boston is positioned with assets to pursue Skubal, joining a possible bidding war with teams like the Mariners and Mets.
If acquired, Skubal might join Garrett Crochet, potentially forming a top American League rotation for the Red Sox.

title: Judge temporarily halts patron saint statues in Quincy, but PETA wants to help
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A judge temporarily blocked Quincy's installation of two patron saint statues, citing their religious significance.
PETA offers to fund the statues if Quincy adds a St. Francis of Assisi statue, promoting compassion towards animals.
The ACLU filed a lawsuit against Quincy, and the city hired Becket Fund to appeal the judge's injunction.

title: Bill Belichick commends Drake Maye for an ‘outstanding’ start with Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick praised Patriots' QB Drake Maye on the 'Let's Go!' podcast for his strong performance this season.
Drake Maye has led the Patriots to a 7-2 record, with 2,285 passing yards and 17 touchdown passes.
Maye is a top MVP candidate with DraftKings giving him the third-best odds behind Josh Allen and Patrick Mahomes.
